subject: Communication
title: Agenda Setting: What Media Tells You to Think About
description: A quick, practical guide to Agenda Setting: What Media Tells You to Think About.

hook.text: Media may not tell you what to think. But it's remarkably good at telling you what to think about.

buildup.text: McCombs and Shaw's agenda-setting theory: the issues media covers most become the issues the public considers most.

discovery.text: If a news channel covers crime 24/7, viewers believe crime is rising â€” even when statistics show it's falling.

twist.text: What media doesn't cover matters equally. Issues absent from coverage become invisible to public consciousness.

climax.text: Media literacy means asking: 'Who decided this was news? What's being covered â€” and what's being ignored?'

punchline.text: The news doesn't show you the world. It shows you a selection of it.

quiz.question: What does agenda-setting theory describe?
options: Media tells people what to think
Media influences what people think about by choosing coverage topics
